fact_1.content: Over 70% of our communication is nonverbal, including body language, facial expressions, and gestures.

fact_2.content: Appropriate eye contact typically lasts 3-5 seconds in Western cultures before a brief break is needed.

fact_3.content: Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS) uses visual symbols to develop communication skills and has been effective for individuals with autism.

fact_4.content: There are six universally recognized facial expressions: happiness, sadness, fear, disgust, anger, and surprise.

fact_5.content: The ability to recognize social cues develops gradually throughout childhood and continues to improve into adolescence.

fact_6.content: Successful adaptive communication involves recognizing the needs of your conversation partner and adjusting your communication style accordingly.

fact_7.content: Speech-generating devices (SGDs) can help individuals with complex communication needs express themselves effectively.

fact_8.content: Prosody, the rhythm, stress, and intonation of speech, helps convey meaning and emotion beyond the actual words used.

fact_9.content: Environmental factors like noise, poor lighting, or distractions can significantly impact communication effectiveness.

fact_10.content: Augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) apps on tablets can provide individuals with customizable communication options that grow with their needs.

fact_11.content: Proxemics, the study of personal space, classifies distances as intimate (0-18 inches), personal (18 inches-4 feet), social (4-12 feet), and public (12+ feet).

fact_12.content: Maintaining eye contact while speaking indicates confidence, while avoiding eye contact may suggest discomfort or dishonesty in Western cultures.

fact_13.content: Blissymbols is a semantic graphical language that uses simple symbols to represent concepts rather than words, allowing for complex communication without written language.

fact_14.content: Paralanguage refers to how something is said rather than what is said, including tone, pitch, volume, and speed of speech.

fact_15.content: Eye-tracking technology allows individuals with limited motor control to communicate by selecting screen elements using only their eye movements.
